@awelfle Are hiring managers expecting an entire portfolio as a website, or just a website with some information about the candidate?  I don’t know why you couldn’t share a deck, which you’re going to need anyway, if someone needs the whole portfolio.

@julianderstands And like I said, a simple website that confirms you are a real person working in UX is a nice thing to have, but if a candidate was deciding between a website portfolio and PDF portfolio, I say PDF all day long.
@julianderstands I mean one reason you wouldn’t do it is because not everyone has the hours in the day to build a personal brand, some people just need jobs.

I wonder if it's getting lost in translation. I think a personal website that pops up when you get Googled, that has a flattering photo of you and an abbreviated resume and links to any design writing you've done, great, nice. But necessary?

I keep hearing from folks aspiring to UX roles that have been told they need to build websites and have their portfolio on a website. Who's telling them that and why? 

Website seems like a nice to have. You'll *need* a PDF portfolio for many application processes, though.

Stories can also be about how you helped a customer or coworker in non-ideal circumstances. Not every designer is set up for success in an organization that has actually created room for them to build the kinds of "case studies" everyone thinks they need for their portfolios.

I like the story framing better because a story can be a small thing that had a big impact, or that illustrates a point (in this case about you) well. It doesn't have to be about a whole project. It doesn't have to have a 1:1 relationship with something big that got "shipped".

Management consultancies with hundreds or thousands of employees publish actual case studies, often about months- or years-long projects. You're just a person. Tell me a story, like we're fast new friends at a favorite bar.
I like to think of them more as "work stories". Just that. Tell me a story about your work.
Having "case studies" as the term of art and primary categorical unit for what comprises an individual designer's portfolio sends the wrong message and creates an unrealistically high bar.

How is energy moving through our ecosystem? Who are the actors inside and outside of our organization? What are the natural processes we haven't yet given name to (and therefore can't talk about or improve)?

A grade-school diagram of a rainforest ecosystem focuses on how energy flows through the rainforest. Production and consumption, respiration and decomposition. Players, yes, but also processes.

If your content and digital strategy conversations feel stuck, consider the forest.
Useful (digital) ecosystem maps that help us align and move forward document our understanding of how the entire ecosystem *operates*, it's why and how, not just the components of which it is made.
It's still just a list if you put bullet points into bubbles but don't describe the relationships between them.

Ecology, the field from which designers borrow the metaphor of ecosystems, is about *relationships* between organisms, and with their environment.

For my money, it's not an ecosystem map if you aren't describing relationships. It's not enough to list channels and stakeholders.
Your levels should describe competencies, not responsibilities. Do not jam governance / content strategy / RACI into your comp levels.

“Here’s what you’ll be responsible for as a senior designer.”
“Nice, awesome. So there’s a junior and mid-level to do this other stuff?”
“Haha no you’ll have to do all of that, too.”
Jobs aren’t roles. It’s cute and all to describe responsibilities on a leveling/seniority chart, but if you’re not committed to staffing someone at each of those levels that is a fiction.

"Because you can’t just give people a bunch of rules and expect that they’re suddenly going to know how to write because if that was the case, they would already be good writers because that’s how they try to teach us writing in school." 2/2

"If you give somebody a rule, you can give them a tool. If you give them a tool, to me is anything that helps people think or work through a problem. Meeting agendas, worksheets, tips, checklists, any of that kind of stuff." 1/2

“You always have to be concise.” Well, you don’t always have to be concise. Most of the time you should be concise. Sometimes you want to be incredibly verbose and that’s a choice that you should make contextually. If the best practice is choose words contextually...I’ll co-sign.

On coaching as a model as a UX writer: "I would rather just personally help a designer understand the flow of the design challenge and user need clearly enough for them to make the right word choice than for me to write it for them."

"What’s wrong with being the writer? Who decided that writing was a bad word? Who decided that writing was a small idea? Who decided that words … I don’t just do words. Well, geez, if you did, plenty of people just do words and make a pretty penny out of it..."

"Someone asked me this morning in a conversation about what inspires or motivates my work. And an easy answer for that one, that I will use until my retirement I imagine, is just: Users. I think users and what your users need is the point where we all come together."
"When I go in and consult with a team, the org chart tells me nothing. The job titles tell me nothing. I have to talk to people to understand what they do."

"I think roles are something we don’t talk about enough in design and in design work. Articulating those roles to me is more important and is what people need to do to get a piece of work done together and that’s a lot more important than how the org chart looks."

"I’m glad that embedding content designers or UX writers ... works for different organizations. I don’t think there is an ideal model. I think that, putting on my content strategist hat for a minute, the ideal model for me is one that is well documented and well socialized."

"[Content job t]itles aside, the most important thing to me is that if you’re part of a product team, if you’re part of a design team, I think that it’s important intellectually, personally, philosophically, to think of yourself as a designer."

It's not chicken and the egg. It's not that no one will give you a junior UX writer job because you've never been a junior UX writer. But you might not getting the junior UX writing job because you don't have any related work experience, e.g. customer support or marketing writing

UX design is not easy and there's a lot to learn about it. Content design is not easy and there's a lot to learn about it. You need _work_ experience and an understanding of how to collaborate with people. If you have _no_ adjacent work experience at _all_, it will be a struggle.
(I am tweeting this because I have to explain it to people on LinkedIn several times a week.)

The UX writing challenge thing is good, I am glad it exists, lots of people find it valuable.

But you can not have a vague interest in design, do a few writing exercises on your own, and expect to magically land a job at a big tech company as a junior UX writer.

@KatJEngel You're getting at my larger point. People think remote can't work because it's not about remote, it's about how the work is structured. If you structure the work appropriately, either remote or in-person can work. I *like* offices and snacks and whiteboards. But not necessary.
@KatJEngel I'm all for the occasional off-site. Especially because those usually require advanced planning and agendas and are way more efficient than weeks worth of meetings!

@KatJEngel I guess I haven't experienced that. Do you think that that increased difficulty is a compelling argument in favor of gasoline-fueled commutes, child care costs, office buildings and parking lots that sit empty at least as much as they get used, etc?

If your remote work "culture" is endless zoom meetings where people talk at each other and you aren't collaborating on design work in real time, holding structured workshops with agendas, and taking advantage of higher-bandwidth async options like video, welp! Of course it sucks.

It's true that collaborating in person and jamming around a white board is more effective than never collaborating, or only ever having "meetings". But don't assume there aren't better, even more effective ways to collaborate and share knowledge than what you had in the office.

@KatJEngel Why is it more efficient in person than via screenshare?

Why not make a video that they could watch on their own time and not have to interrupt their flow at all?

If your design-led or product-led or customer-obsessed technology company is struggling to be effective with remote and hybrid work, it's because your design ops and content ops already sucked and couldn't take any additional strain. It's not because of where the keyboards are.

This may be a shocker to some people, but most actual labor at a technology company happens when humans are sitting in front of keyboards. Whether those keyboards are located near or far from each other does not affect the quality of the labor.

RT @awelfle: My friend @scottkubie is offering a cool thing for folks who are looking for content jobs — a thoughtful, unique 6-week series…
How can I help you?

Sure, some folks only want to post that LinkedIn photo of their new employee swag from a FAANG job.

But for everyone else – which is almost everyone – I hope I can be a beacon of sanity and opportunity. You *have* the skills. There *are* other ways forward. 

So let me know...

And for people who want more structure and guidance in navigating their content career, I've just launched a new Content Career Accelerator program. It's a personalized six-week program to help people get unstuck and moving forward in their content career. https://t.co/sIgYQSMBqJ

One way I'm trying to help individuals is through my UX Content Office Hours. They're free, small-group sessions to meet, network, and commiserate with me and others trying to break in or level up.

https://t.co/pqq5zxEkuX

And I want to help companies everywhere understand and value content appropriately, so that people can take good, well-paying jobs in fields that aren't focused on keeping people addicted to their phones and stoking resentment to increase engagement.

I personally want to spend more time empowering people to find great content jobs hiding in plain sight, reframe existing experience to get the pay and leveling they deserve, and create WAY more opportunities for content folks beyond a smattering of entry-level roles on UX teams.

When it comes to UX content careers, we don't talk nearly enough about content strategy, editorial, content management, and knowledge management roles when nearly every single company needs and hires for those roles, even if they don't make apps or have a UX department.

It also sucks that people with solid backgrounds and 5, 10, 20 years of communications experience feel they need to take a remedial bootcamp for a "certification" in order to merely get an interview with UX hiring managers who've only been in their own field for a few years.

And it sucks that so many people with solid, evergreen, foundational skills in writing, editorial, and communications aren't able to get past recruiters or phone screeners because of the job titles on their resumes.

It's a travesty that many feel their only option to "break in" to a UX content career is Facebook (a company that employs around 0.000016% of the global workforce) or some other huge, morally-dubious tech company.

And there are so, so, so many industries and organizations where content design and content strategy skills are useful and used. Tech companies aren't the only kinds of companies. UX jobs aren't the only kinds of content jobs.

There are so, so, so many paths into careers in content strategy, content design, and UX writing. 

Nearly every one of the hundreds and hundreds of people I've talked to in this field have taken a different path to where they are.

Remote work is the easiest scapegoat for leaders who failed to truly support their people during a difficult time.

If you’ve had your first experience with working remotely in the last two years, consider that a lot of the things that seem hard about it might just be because we’re in a pandemic and everyone is the tiredest they’ve ever been in their life, not specifically from being remote.

If it was just “so much better” around a whiteboard, your leaders probably suck at facilitation and meeting planning. Personally I plan to continue using digital whiteboards even as in-person classes and workshops resume.
If you relied on break rooms and hallway chatter to socialize important ideas and information, you had a massive internal comms problem.

If your remote workforce doesn’t feel like they can socialize, relax, and engage on topics other than work, you have a culture problem that foosball tables and kombucha on tap cannot fix and was not fixing.
I’m so salty I’m repeating myself! I’m so salty I’m repeating myself!

@uxwriterhere That’s great. I’m saying you might need to apply for different sorts of roles and work closer to what you want from inside. Internal candidates that know the product, but only have a little bit of experience with the specialization (e.g. content design) are a much easier sell.

@uxwriterhere I can’t know if this is the case for you personally, but I’ve met a lot of folks who are deadset on getting a titled content design or UX writing role, and that stubbornness is keeping them from getting a good next job that will let them actually learn/do those things.
In physical offices some people never venture beyond their own floor and nearest break room. In a remote world I can connect with anyone anywhere at once.

If you’re 100% remote, everyone works at the same office. Most tech companies already have several if not dozens of physical offices and global locations … so every argument they have about “running into people in the break room” is stupid on the face of it.
It’s fine if you like being in an office more but there is nothing that can’t happen remotely, from serendipitous conversations to a true sense of culture and belonging, that can’t happen remotely.

@uxwriterhere Most people I know, myself included, took whatever job as close to product/UX as they could get with the experience they had and did content strategy anyway and worked on moving inward and upward. Customer support, for instance, or a marketing role.

SME interviews tend to inform content creation. They help you validate assumptions, check facts, and make your content as good as it can be. And interviews are only one way to involve your SMEs; you can also involve them via pair writing, editorial ideation workshops, etc.

Subject matter experts (SMEs) might well also be stakeholders, especially if they own a topic or content area within the web presence, but their role as a SME is separate from their role as a stakeholder.

Stakeholder interviews come way at the beginning. They inform your situation analysis. They help you identify risks, opportunities, and strategic themes/pillars. They're for figuring out who's who, what they need, and how you'll need to guide/guard/shepherd toward success.

Amateur content strategy mistake is conflating stakeholders and subject matter experts. 

If you're only interviewing subject matter experts you're probably doing content marketing, not content strategy.

Mark the calendar: November 14, 2021. New mission: Make Content (big C) matter as much as Product. Will take Information Architecture along for the ride. 

My lifetime of experience has been that every digital project is an absolute fucking upside-down shit show without Content.

UX Writing as a UX design specialization isn’t the way. Content Design as some sort of UX research and editorial planning hybrid isn’t the way. “Product Content Strategy” as a secretarial role within Product isn’t the way. 

Content is the way. Capital C.
Content is bigger, older, and harder than Product. Content can steer Product and amplify their effectiveness, if you let it.
If we want to get there, we’ll need Content people to stop giving ground to Product, stop working in the shadows, stop letting the org chop rungs off their career ladders.

Content could (should) be just as big as Product, in the broad, euphemistic way that Product is used to describe an overall philosophy and set of tools, skills, roles, and activities that helps organizations prioritize and make money.

@baileysteinfadt I don’t know if I could say with confidence what industrial *engineering* comprises. Just my own knowledge gap.

But the roots of UX are in HCI, user-centered design, and design thinking, which primarily derive from industrial *design* practices.
The good stuff is in the books. It's evergreen. You don't know it if you've only read articles and watched videos and done bootcamps. Read the books. Beginning to end. Read 'em again.
My new number one piece of advice for leveling up your UX career is to stop reading the articles and start reading the books.

I don't even get that many requests most days. But a lot of other folks, folks from even-more-marginalized backgrounds, who've had an even harder time getting to where they are, are even MORE tired and get even more selfish requests.

So: Do your reading and don't be a dick.
Watch the videos. Here, look, tens of hours of free UX content education: https://t.co/Ao50ob0lRb

Table stakes on doing the work is reading the goddamn books. READ THE BOOKS. This isn't rocket science. Read Content Strategy for the Web. Read The Elements of Content Strategy (which is FREE now). Read Content Design. Read Making Sense of Any Mess.

It was hard as fuck to get where I am. I hope it's easier for you, I really do. But if I'd known where the shortcuts were I would have taken them, believe me. I still don't know. You gotta do the work, man.
And jesus christ if I ever was going to ask someone for something I took a minute to read up about them and what they do and who they are and how what I'm asking for might be at all relevant to them.

I was able to build those relationships through putting in the *work*. I showed up to events and volunteered and asked questions, applied and applied and applied to conferences, created my own spaces like a Meetup group to be able to offer something in return.

I wouldn't be where I am in my career without the help of so, so, SO many people. People who I built a *relationship* with, and of whom I made very specific and intentional requests. Or who, through our relationship, saw opportunities to offer me something I didn't know I needed.

Allow me to be the bad guy: Paying it forward does not mean taking literally any request to "pick my brain" about getting into a UX content career. I never insulted someone by demanding the secret shortcuts to get to where they are, because I knew there weren't any.
It's small, but just could not be more irked when a moment of truth touchpoint with a brand comes via a transactional email with a big angry NO REPLY DO NOT REPLY sender name. Just terribly tacky.

This may seem like silly semantics, but the top thing I see even mid-level UX writers and content designers asking for help with in community groups is "the CTA text". They've gotten too narrow and think the problem is a word choice. But it's almost always a framing problem.

Because of naming choices by Hubspot and other landing page builders, folks have taken to referring to the buttons themselves as "CTA buttons". 

Fine. That's best read as "the button that supports your call to action", not "the thing that *is* a call to action".
The call to action might start before the screen that even contains that button.
Look at the button in context. Mostly, a button needs to specify what action it actually performs. The presented rationale for why a user would want to *take* that action is your call to action.
If you're struggling with what to write on the button, you've probably narrowed your focus too much.

“Secure the hill” is a mission. The world that we hope exists after we win the war that securing the hill helped us win is the vision. Mission statements are incredibly important logistically, but conceptually are about as important as a grocery list.

Vision first. 

Missions support visions. Missions should be as readily abandoned as they are undertaken.

Your organization does not exist because of its mission. The existence of your organization is part of a mission that (hopefully) serves a vision.

Even if you find something no one else has thought of, you'll have 10 competitors a month after funding.

Products that fail fail because they lacked a compelling point of view or never successfully articulated it. The rest is details.

I'm probably the 5000th UX designer to call out LinkedIn's myriad deceptive design techniques intent on scraping your contacts, so they're unlikely to change any of this, but YOU can avoid being an asshole in the stuff you design. I believe in you!

3) Use descriptive text for the link such as "Learn more about how LinkedIn uses your phone number" (also an accessibility win)
4) Have the headline reflect both outcomes, or neither (e.g. "Add your phone number" or "A phone number secures your account and helps people find you")

1) If a single user action causes multiple outcomes, list those outcomes discretely, e.g. with bullet points.
2) Even better, make the secondary outcome (letting contacts find you) opt-in via checkbox, rather than an opt-out buried in settings (and when it might be too late).

Ideally, these two actions (enabling 2FA and adding a phone number to allow connections to find you that way) wouldn't be connected at all.

But even if they are, some easy design tweaks would make this interaction less deceptive.
There's also a bad and dangerous assumption here that anyone who has your phone number has it for a good reason and is a good actor. That's unsafe design.

A subtle deceptive design practice that doesn't get called out enough is headline/copy mismatch. HCI says one button = one outcome. Rhetoric says headlines/titles summarize contents. Both violated here to sneak in some privacy-violating, growth-hacking nonsense. https://t.co/1MrjMgV2eD

"Users visit our homepage more than any other page on the site! That means it's really important to them!"

"This guy uses the doorknob to get into his house every time he comes home! Doorknobs are really important to him!"

Users care as much about what's on your homepage as they do about what's on the bulletin board between the two sets of automatic glass doors at Target. Don't you love to stop between those two sets of glass doors and read a bulletin board?

Organizations always talk about their homepage as the "front door" of their website, and you know what? They're absolutely right. 

In that a front door is something guests move past with barely a thought, and that has no bearing on the experience of being in the house.

Your users don't give nearly as much of a fuck about your homepage as y'all do.

Amount of fuck y'all give: way too much
Amount of fuck they give: almost none

I've gotten to meet and collaborate frequently with folks from the @Postlight agency fairly often over the past year or so. My esteem grows for them in every interaction. Really cool cats I'd put into consideration for any digital initiatives you have planned for 2022 or beyond.

Designers and devs I've worked with who do this can often get the words 95% of the way there all by themselves, and all I need to do are some light edits for style guide adherence.

Bonus: they usually find opportunities to remove cruft and simplify the experience.

Not a knock, just an observation. And a quick way to level up your UX writing: Get in the habit of describing (with bullet points, for instance) what's going on during the interaction _before_ you try to write the interface copy. Get the story straight first.

The top reason I see designers and developers struggle with words for a given interaction is because they have not really truly fully articulated to themselves what is happening during that specific interaction. 

You have to know the whole story to write the blurb on the cover.

"It is difficult to get a man to understand something when his salary depends upon his not understanding it." 

If your salary depends on shipping and moving the little numbers on the dashboard, you're not going to be very interested in content strategy.

Most product and design leaders already understand the value of words and writing. What they don't understand, or don't want to understand, is that truly getting the words right requires a fundamentally different approach to design and product development than they're used to.

RT @dandoescontent: @scottkubie Absolutely this. Things can, and usually should be different or distinct. When everything looks or behaves…

A consistent experience consistently meets user expectations for behavior and meaning. Absolute sameness in all permutations of a given component (or expression of a given idea) across an experience is not required to achieve that consistency. It may even hinder it.
If I tell one person I’m fine and another person that I’m miserable, that _might_ be inconsistency. Or it might be that I was fine before and feel miserable now (bad tacos, perhaps).
If someone asks how I’m doing and I say “fine and dandy”, and an hour later someone else asks and I answer “pretty, pretty good”, I am not being inconsistent. I’m just expressing myself differently.

Consistency is an important part of designing great experiences. 

But consistency is not what many designers think it is. Things can be different without creating “inconsistencies”.

Call me crazy but I feel like maybe the extremely well-paid designers and engineers of your favorite social media platform are better equipped to enable content accessibility then your cousin Greg.

Should we scold individual social media users for having fun with emoji that might make it more difficult on screen reader software, or scold the product designers who haven’t engineered their platform to account for it?

Corporations should of course make every effort to create accessible content, but I don’t think we should do the “individual responsibility” thing here. Does every Jane Q. User need to know to write screen-readable camelcase hashtags, or should the platform require/encourage it?

The people yelling at me have found that a big, encompassing definition of content design is USEFUL to them in their organizations. Great! Bully for them! Neither definition is wrong. The only wrong thing is thinking one or the other is the right one.

And it makes it really hard to teach people who have no context for these conversations how to navigate our field and find useful resources, or how to find the right kinds of jobs for them.

So I'm not "wrong", because it's a USEFUL definition for me. That's all that matters.

A for instance: I find it very *useful* to define content design as: a user-centered method of writing.

People get really mad about that, and yell at me and tell me that content design is oh-so-much-more. 

That oh-so-much-more is *not* useful to me. It obscures and conflates. https://t.co/YYp446n9WY

Oh, and if you're not going to follow that piece of advice, consider this one instead: The right place for hard-line, true-or-false, Define the Damn Thing design discipline conversations is happy hour at the conference hotel bar.
I invite y'all to consider the spectrum of "more or less useful" as opposed to the black-and-white thinking of "true or false" in these discussions. Okay thanks.

The best teachers in content strategy, IA, etc, tend to start their intro courses with a whole host of definitions and perspectives, offer multiple frameworks, and teach YOU and your team how to form an understanding of these disciplines, which is the actually important thing.
If someone is offering you The One True Definition, it's because they've got something to sell. (Often literally: courses, trainings, certifications, etc.)

As it would be too cumbersome otherwise, thought leaders offering definitions in these domains often say "is" when they mean "is best understood as", or sometimes they say "is" when they mean "is understood by ME to be" or "is" when they mean "is basically, but not exhaustively".

Is UX writing the same thing as Content Design?

If that's useful to your understanding and work, then yes. If not, then no.

Humans aren't the dictionary. No practitioner or agency owns the definitions of these things, which are all made up to begin with.

https://t.co/iQQXE7N0tG
When teams tell me that everyone in their organization thinks they can write, I say: "Great! Let's run with that and get them writing in a user-centered way."

Which is just to say, think long and hard about what's going on in your organization before parroting the trope that "Content isn't valued because everyone thinks they can write."

That may cause a hiccup here and there, but I think it's actually pretty far down the issues list.

It's why some of the most notable (and arguably successful) content strategists and information architects are consultants rather than working staff roles. As a consultant, someone has explicitly paid you to come in and make sense of things after the pain becomes too great.

It's difficult to do great work as a UI or UX designer when there's not enough clarity (of product vision, of value proposition, of user need, of business goal, etc etc).

It's pretty much fucking impossible as a writer.

The reason that so many content folks don't feel valued is not because design and product people don't understand the value of words. (I've rarely had anyone argue with me that words aren't important.) It's more that teams don't appropriately value sensemaking activities.

Meetup has its own idea of "organizer" discrete from the common usage, which basically means "person who pays for the account". When someone steps down as the Meetup-dot-com organizer, Meetup leaves the group up for grabs. Every member gets a message about taking it over.

Anyway, this has been a fun little thing and I'm going to keep it going. Thanks if you've been part of it, and thanks for reading this far if you're thinking about it. Gonna start a thread to give shout-outs to my BMAC supporters. I've been kind of sheepish about it, but no more!

Now, the most likely outcome of this thread is that other folks in my space will ape this approach and not actually support or acknowledge me, but I'm kind of used to that at this point. And why I value the actual support I get through things like this SO MUCH.

Unfortunately, as you might notice, the BMAC platform is a little rough, so some of the content previews and such are as well, but this isn't some big corporate enterprise, it's just me. If something isn't working I'll help make it right.

Slides and notes from Communicating Change (To Your Users), which is one of my earliest UX talks and honestly probably one of the best, or at least most important: 

https://t.co/bSnLrjxKkc

Slides for my 2020 presentation How Smart Teams Create and Train Writers: 

https://t.co/CqfFlhaUzq

First, some of the Extras:

Slides and notes from my conference presentation How to Get the Writing Done for Products.

https://t.co/2HnJbIZXPG

The content right now is mostly from my work in UX, but it's going to be about whatever I want it to be. Mostly: thoughts and links and tools and ideas for people who like to make stuff. Whatever that stuff might be. I'm a How kind of guy.

So instead of deleting it, I'm adding more stuff. A month or so ago (timey-wimey etc) I turned Membership back on. I've added new Extras that are free for Members, and scheduled some posts that are free for either members or all supports (including one-time donations).

But then another "coffee" comes in and man do I feel that rush. I really, really, really like making stuff *for* y'all, to feel like you're on my side. It's helped me through the pandemic, to be sure, and encouraged me to think hard about what all I have to offer.
Every single day I've thought about deleting it. It makes me feel weird and vulnerable. Who am I to take people's money for stuff I would have done anyway? What do I even have to offer?

BMAC is kind of a weird conglomeration of features ripped off from other crowdfunding and digital commerce platforms. I've experimented off and on with their "extras" and "memberships", but mostly it's been folks throwing $4 to $12 my way to say "I like what you do. Keep it up."

And to my surprise, people donated! I recently broke $500 in total contributions, which is not nothing. Cynically, numerically, over a year that pays for...3 app subscriptions, maybe. But it's also been incredibly motivating. It's my *favorite* money to make, hands-down.

I didn't feel like I had enough going on to start a Patreon, but I wanted to at least open the door for folks to throw money my way to support my projects. Most notably, I'd just started a new newsletter, @uxwritingevents, that was somewhat time-intensive.

About a year ago, I was a month or so (I don't do calendars, just roll with it) into my COVID layoff and trying out all kinds of experiments. One experiment was opening a tip jar on the site Buy Me a Coffee: https://t.co/1l5gFTmSq1

I have led very expensive content strategy consulting projects for organizations that do not have anyone with "UX" in their job title or job description.
Every single organization needs content strategy. Only certain types of organizations need UX writers.

If you’re sick of your comms job (or just the pay) and know you want to work for a tech company, UX writing is a great thing to learn. If you want the flexibility to work for just about *any* kind of company, or to build a consulting practice, look at content strategy.

An *overly*-strong interest in tools can be revealing, however. For instance, when I was selling content strategy consulting, it was often a red flag when prospective clients insisted that we have deep experience with their particular CMS.

RT @scottkubie: Some folks have objected to framing content design as writing. 

I’m saying content design is _best_ understood as a method…

@the_omolewa I do. Content strategy is best understood as an operational planning discipline ... systems, tools, structure. Content design is best understood as a user-centered method of content creation – bringing UCD and design thinking to bear on writing and planning specific content.

What your content strategists *do* is not the same as what content strategy *is*.

What your content designers *do* is not the same as what content design *is*.

What your UX writers *do* is not the same as what UX writing *is*.

Jobs are not roles. Roles are not disciplines.
@PunktHQ I agree with you?

@EllenAFeldman @ronbronson I think my preference is generic job titles as in corporate gigs (e.g. Experience Designer III), highly-specific roles & responsibilities articulated for any given piece of work, and functionally-narrow definitions of the scope and spirit of each respective design discipline.
@jonasdees I've been my own dentist and barber since last February. Which makes it content strategy work now, apparently.
@ronbronson If anything that a content designer does is content design and if anything that an IA does is IA and anything a UX writer does is UX writing ... why even have these labels?

@ronbronson I am asking if borrowing a tool/methodology as a practitioner of a discipline makes it PART of the discipline most closely matches the borrower's job title. 

I say no, but the degree to which this opinion seems to make people mad suggests that I am in the minority.

After admitting that, you can then invite the help of your content and communications friends to articulate a more coherent vision in a way that will be more useful to your workers and resonant with your customers.

To nurture that vulnerability you must first admit, and continue admitting, that you don't have all of the answers, that we are in fact making this up as we go along, and that if we had a more coherent vision, we would share it with you.
Content strategy – a.k.a. functional operational clarity for digital product teams  – is not a phase to be added on your burndown chart. It is a vulnerability that must be nurtured.
That clarity does not come from design sprints. It's honest answers to the Really Big Questions.

They are fed up because they want CLARITY. They are there, and they are over-qualified, and they would love to just dive in and do their best work. But they can't, because what was a decent way to build software (Agile) is now your entire organizational ecosystem.

I know I'm a weirdo liberal arts loudmouth, but friends: I have been in *so many* board rooms, at so many all-hands, have drank so many bottled waters while fussing with my tie ... and talked to SO MANY people in communications at YOUR companies who are fed. the. fuck. up.

Product visions, design principles, Big Hairy Audacious Goals, mission statements, brand decks and so on are all well and good, but generally do not provide the *functional* clarity your people need to enthusiastically dive in and do their best work.

That's because content strategy is ultimately about clarity. A content strategy mindset provides *functional* clarity to the People Doing the Work that is all too often absent. (The best content strategists actively recoil at the phrase "I'm sure we'll figure it out.")

A truly empowered content strategy team can actively mitigate against the conceptual debt naturally accrued by Agile, design sprints, and other "move fast and break things" approaches to making stuff.
That payoff? It hurts. Like. Hell. It can fracture teams, if not whole organizations.

It's not a malicious lie. I have reveled in the constraint and focus a product sprint provides. They're fun! And help us brush aside a great deal of inconsequential questions and worries.

But, untended, they also rapidly build conceptual debt that must eventually be paid off.
This is a lie.

Most sprints do not afford the time to ask these questions, let alone answer them. 

The magic of the sprint promises that if we just keep building and shipping and building and shipping, all answers will be revealed in time.

Content strategy, at its best, helps teams ask and answer Really Big Questions about organizational vision, brand voice, mission, messages, targets, and tone. (Or if you prefer The Quad: questions about content workflow, governance, substance, and structure.)
Content strategy is a planning discipline heavily influenced by publishing, service design, and business strategy. It does not happen two weeks at a time inside of text fields in Figma.

If you told me you were struggling to "fit" content strategy into your agile product management approach, I would not be any more surprised than if you told me you were struggling to fit an elephant into your glovebox.

Capitalism sucks and the job market sucks, so, broadly, job seekers of all stripes have my sympathy. I don't have a ton of sympathy for folks who expect to immediately parachute into six-figure tech jobs after taking a six-week course.

That experience could come through, for instance, a customer support role. Or doing marketing writing *for* a product company! Get as close to the thing you want to do as you can, stay curious, and raise a hand when there's a chance to work on stuff closer to what you want.

Knowing how to do graphic design doesn't necessarily prepare you to do UX design, and knowing how to write doesn't necessarily prepare you to do UX writing. You need to build experience with UCD processes, and working as part of product teams.

Technical writing. Knowledge management. UX design. Information architecture. Even doing software development or front-end design ... these jobs give a lot of related experience for UX writing that being a marketing writer might not have given you.

Wish I'd a happier answer for people who've discovered UX writers and content designers are in demand.

These jobs are not easy. You do in fact have to demonstrate experience. The terms are relatively new, yes, but the work is not. Many newcomers have years of related experience.

The way to create a portfolio for a discipline in which you have no experience is to either gain experience or to re-contextualize experience you already have. A "portfolio" based on genuinely *zero* experience is just a book report.

@pottedmeat Broad "What do you think about X?" questions can be great! Love to answer on podcasts/panels. When strangers email or message me looking for help, I'm much more likely to have the time/interest/energy to respond to detailed questions that have an A or B, yes or no kind of answer.

Open: Any tips for someone in Situation X?

Specific: I'm in Situation X. I'm thinking about using Approach Y. I have Concern Z about Approach Y. Is that a valid concern? Any tips for mitigating it?

A well-articulated question in my inbox where a specific answer is possible is like a treat. I get to help someone without much effort, and feel like I'm knocking something off my to-do list, which builds momentum.

Big open-ended questions are basically the opposite.

If you "don't care" and think it's all a bit silly, bully for you. Maybe your diamond won't shine as brightly. It's still a diamond. Great! Go do some good work and shush up.

These distinctions help others find their people, conferences, books, career inspiration, mentors, etc.

Diamonds are just rocks. We cut and shape them and polish the facets to help the diamond shine more brilliantly. That's all that these various distinctions are doing for us, adding a surface that makes that diamond sparkle in a new way.

Individuals who loudly ask (complain) "Aren't all these things the same? Isn't it all just [copywriting/strategy/design/technical writing/UX]?" tend to be incurious people with large gaps in their understanding of even the "one thing" they think it all "is".

Understanding the reason our industry has developed these distinctions can help you understand your own work better, and help you anticipate the full breadth of content, design, and strategic considerations you might need to make for any sizable design undertaking.

I also want to say that these distinctions are not always *important*, just that they exist. They are, in a way, all facets on the larger diamond of Design. All of the work a CS or IA does or a UX writer does can be understood as design. Even the writing. Especially the writing.

Someone DM'd to ask about books for each of these areas. 

I'll share some recommendations in a moment. First, I want to say that by no means do you need to develop expertise in all of these areas to practice any one of them. Tons of skill overlap in each discipline. https://t.co/qL9WnLZEy2

@webmeadow Fair. These distinctions don’t have to be in job titles though. I advocate for broad job titles. 

Only hiring people who’ve already had the job title UX Writer to do UX writing is HR idiocy, not an unavoidable result of each discipline finding its voice.

Much like information architecture, your organization (and each individual site, channel, campaign, and app) has a content strategy whether you've intentionally crafted it or not.

@peripherlvision Design systems make for a good analogy. Every product team needs some sort of designer. But not every product team needs a design systems expert *on* that team, just in the organization. The team _makes use of_ the design system. The team _makes use of_ the content strategy.

@peripherlvision The distinction is about them being "on" the team or not. I am not saying "never needs anything that a content strategist does". If org/domain/dept. has a CS, that CS may have already established tools, rules, processes, etc. that teams can make use of.
@peripherlvision I am not using them interchangeably. I am suggesting that not every product design team needs to have a content strategist ON that team.
@peripherlvision Did I say content professional or content strategist?

No, not every product team needs a content strategist. But every organization does. 

(Depending on how granular your org chart, probably every department/division/domain does, too.)

If a button does two things, the best solution is to make the button do one thing.

But sometimes? After all your presentations? All the user testing? All the conversations with engineering? The button is going to do two things.

And the words better damn make that clear.

Writing for interfaces involves more than writing, of course. It's about being part of a design team and all that comes along with that. Sometimes that means making the best of  constraints with words. It's sometimes the most important work a UX writer can do.

As UX Writing experiences semantic diffusion I’m seeing more posts from UX randos where someone has written good, clear, helpful text describing a poor process or complex situation, accompanied with a comment like “LOL #UXwriting fail”

Actually more of a win, in that case.
same https://t.co/2fSZGOMN8y

...yet designers who know all this will beat themselves up because they can't write word-perfect copy on their first try. It's silly!

Make a mess! Sketch out words (yes, with Sharpies!) Write protocopy, half-baked sentences, jot out ideas. Just get words onto that canvas!

A place I see a lot of designers get stuck with writing is that they suddenly forget everything they learned about fidelity. We know that sketches aren't mock-ups, mock-ups aren't prototypes, prototypes aren't release candidates. There's a process to getting there...

The good news is that a lot of writing is more like designing than you might realize. A lot of your existing practices – research, stakeholder interviews, design studios, critiques, etc. – can be modified to focus more on words and make the writing easier.

Best practices in design are a last resort, not a first stop. This is especially true with words. Little guidance about language or grammar can be applied universally.

To improve your writing as a designer, the first step is to acknowledge that this shit is HARD.

Writing is really hard in design when you go looking for easy answers. Problem is, writing is still designing. It's not a Mad Lib or a crossword puzzle. There's no single "right" answer for what word goes where. You need to learn HOW to get to writing that works for you.

It's my deep experience and strong belief that the way to improve your writing as a designer is focusing on HOW, not what.

You need new tools and methods. The approaches you learned in school won't cut it. 

That's what my book @designerswrite is about. https://t.co/B4yg3zw4ud

I know there are business pressures influencing some of these patterns, but as an end user it's awfully frustrating to experience daily fundamental violations of basic usability principles from services trying to "personalize" their way to greater engagement.

Stopping watching something isn't the same as undoing having watched it. Unfaving a tweet isn't the same as never having faved it. Unfollowing on Instagram isn't the same as never having followed. Why not?

An example of doing it right: Gmail's 'Undo Send' https://t.co/48WkXanxMe

Will this turd of a film still influence my recommendations? I don't even know! It's all a far cry from true user control and freedom. And this is just one example among so so many. Why even bother to unfollow someone now? The feeds will still show you their content anyway.

• Hilariously (in line with the heuristic) confirm removal: 'Remove from your Watch History? Your watch progress will be reset, and you will no longer see this in Keep Watching.'
• Select 'OK' on a confirmation screen
• Back out of the menus and movie (several presses)

To obliterate "2099: The Soldier Protocol" from my personalized KEEP WATCHING list, I had to:

• Navigate to movie (several presses)
• Open movie (not knowing if it would open or play)
• Navigate to 'Manage Movie' (several presses)
• Select 'Remove from Watch History'
(cont.)

There's an awful movie on Hulu I gave up watching after just a few minutes. In a basic navigation sense, "undoing" the action of playing the movie *was* easy. One button press.

But on a system level, actually undoing it requires over a dozen presses, via an obtuse process.

Nielsen: "Users often choose system functions by mistake and will need a clearly marked "emergency exit" to leave the unwanted state without having to go through an extended dialogue. Support undo and redo."

https://t.co/yR2Io01MeD

Personalization is great but a lot of apps and systems end up deeply violating the "user control & freedom" usability heuristic. 

It's often the case now that you can reverse an action but not actually *undo* it, at least not with anything resembling ease.

Part of the problem is not so much that recruiters and hiring managers don't understand content, but rather that entire organizations misunderstand what design truly is.

I consider myself a designer first and foremost. Design is my worldview. And AS a designer, I'm very happy to inhabit the role of Writer, or Content Strategist, or Information Architect. It's absolutely silly to me to not understand these roles as design roles.
I think the winds are shifting. More and more teams are valuing content, writing, and information architecture as mission-critical product and UX design skillsets. It's hard, but we're getting there.

In case it helps any content people to hear this:

I also get told I'm "not a product guy" & "not a designer", even with 12 years in the game (over half on product teams), having published a UX book, and given talks and workshops on international UX stages. It sucks. I see you.

The most research-informed, user-centered redesign process will still fail if the product isn't going to be maintained by a user-centered culture.

The UX community could do this on our own, I suppose, but I'd rather the folks charging $1500/head paid someone on their team to do it.

This record helps practitioners find like minds, connect their threads of thought to thinkers who've come before them, and reduce the likelihood of unintentionally claiming to invent a wheel that was invented 5, 10, or 15 years prior.

A for-profit design/UX conference is not an academic conference, but I still think there should be an obligation to maintain a public record of past proceedings (speakers, talk titles, and abstracts).

If your brand was better at user research you’d care a lot less about personalization.

A lot of the conversation within marketing land seems to be either “How do we do [this unethical thing] such that our users don’t perceive it as creepy?” or “How do we push the Overton Window on what our users find acceptable?”

Allowing users to configure an interface or system to suit their preferences is customization. You can enable this w/o knowing/retaining *personal* information about the user. Personalization (as Orwellian marketers understand it) is not necessary to deliver custom experiences.

Users get to decide what is creepy. Not advertisers. To quote Bill Hicks on advertisers: “There’s no rationalisation for what you do and you are Satan’s little helpers.” (That’s the part I can quote without going to Twitter jail.)
Anticipating user needs is not personalization, that’s design. DESIGN.
Drinking spiced rum, building a Star Wars LEGO set, and hate-watching videos about marketing personalization. How’s your Monday night going? (It’s Monday isn’t it?)

Sometimes, your users really do just want to browse your website, read about your company, have fun clicking on links, and experience your brand in a trendy new digital format.

Those times were, roughly, 1991 to 1998.

2) Paid one-hour consultations. You can book and pay for them directly through my site, no SoW required. I'll spend an hour beforehand reviewing anything you want me to look over so we can get a lot done in a little bit of time.

1) Free, reservable open office hours. Right now, I'm holding 3x slots open on Tuesday mornings. I expect/hope to primarily use these slots to help folks with personal topics in their career or job hunt.

I didn't always have the answer. But I felt like I was always able to offer some guidance, or at least encouragement, and a specific next step. 

If this kind of support sounds valuable to you or your team, I'd love to help. Going forward, I have two options:

• presenting UX writing to leadership
training UX writing teams
• content strategy and UX writing in international contexts

... as well as career paths, portfolios, and navigating the complexities of content job titles.

• must-haves before creating a content strategy framework
• better ways for design and product teams to collaborate with UX writers
• understanding where UX writing and content design is headed and adapting for it

• demonstrating progress with major content initiatives to internal audiences
• breaking a huge list of content strategy needs into manageable chunks of work
• demonstrating the impact and value of writing (and getting more resources!)

• managing team handoffs between UX writers (e.g. during a leave of absence)
• adapting marketing and editorial experience to a UX writing role
• building content strategy from scratch inside a fast-moving organization

• being the only writer juggling the needs of multiple product teams
• aligning website positioning behind clear mission and value statements 
• writing for conversion inside of a lengthy acquisition funnel (and balancing sales vs. usability)

• working with subject matter experts to get the best information for what we need
• being the first UX writer at a company and hitting the ground running
• communicating your agency's niche and expertise more clearly

• defining content success in the public sector
• implementing content strategy standards and processes in a large-scale agency
• finding stability when priorities change by the day
• fitting content strategy into a web project when design templates have already been approved

Ran a little experiment with free consulting hours in March and April after getting laid off. 

All told I had 20 conversations with people at all stages of their personal and organizational journeys in content strategy, UX writing, and product.
